Body:
BC-PHOTO-UPDATE-NYT 
   ATTENTION EDITORS: The following photos are part of tonight's
New York Times Photo Package, moving Tuesday, 01/18/00. Photo
clients will automatically receive these photos via AP's
PhotoExpress or may download them from either the Wieck Photo
Database in Dallas at 972-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on Newscom at
305-448-8411. Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling
(888) 603-1036 or 212-556-4204.

   (NYT33) UNDATED -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- OBIT-STONE-B&W -- Irving I.
Stone, who helped turn a small family business, started in 1906,
into the world's second-largest maker of greeting cards, died
Monday at University Hospitals in Cleveland. He was 90 and lived in
Beachwood, Ohio. (1989 The New York Times)

   (NYT32) NEW YORK -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JAN. 23 --
JENNY-LIND-MUSIC -- Jenny Lind, the 19th-century Swedish
Nightingale, in a photograph from 1852 by Matthew B. Brady and
Luther Boswell. If we still hear Lind loud and clear, it is because
her career is the prototype for superstars today. On Saturday, the
American soprano Barbara Bonney will present ``The Legacy of Jenny
Lind,'' at Lincoln Center as the first installment of her
three-part survey of Scandinavian song. (Chrysler Museum of Art/The
New York Times)

   (NYT31) HOLLYWOOD -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JAN. 23 --
CATHERINE-KEENER-FILMS -- Catherine Keener had to be told she was
right for her role in ``Being John Malkovich,'' the dryly surreal
hit in which she stars. Spike Jonze, who directed ``Malkovich,''
categorizes Ms. Keener's ability to be effortlessly hilarious as a
brand of acting that is ``un-flashy. Very real, but complicated.
Naturalistic. More like you're watching a person as opposed to a
character.'' (Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

   (NYT30) NEW YORK -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- ADV. FOR SUN., JAN. 23 --
R-AND-B-MUSIC -- D'Angelo at the offices of Virgin Records on Park
Avenue. Rising to the challenge of becoming a complete
singer-songwriter, he is making new music that is wise, largely
unslick and stubbornly idiosyncratic. There's a widening
groundswell of R-and-B artists - and even some who fit more
naturally in the category of hip-hop - who are sounding like an
antidote to the sameness problem. (Chang W. Lee/The New York Times)
LITE

   (NYT29) NEW YORK -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- BROADWAY-TELEVISED -- Don
Roy King filming ``Smokey Joe's Cafe'' for a new company called the
Broadway Television Network. As early as this fall, the company
plans to start bringing the first of a dozen Broadway shows to the
home screen as they are being performed in the theater over the
next five years. (George M. Gutierrez/The New York Times)

   (NYT28) HOMESTEAD, Fla. -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- FLA-CITRUS-CANKER --
An inspector from the Florida State Department of Agriculture and
Consumer Services inspects a lime grove on Tuesday. for signs of
the deadly canker disease found in the area's groves. Over the
several days, a treacherous and incurable bacteria called citrus
canker has begun migrating from backyard gardens to infect south
Florida's commercial lime, grapefruit and orange groves. (Cindy
Karp/The New York Times)

   (NYT27) UNDATED -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- COKE-MARKETPLACE --
Coca-Cola's recent moves suggest the start of a major shift inside
the company, which Tuesday announced the promotion of Jack L.
Stahl, who has headed Coke's business in North America, as
president and chief operating officer, effective in April. Stahl,
46, will serve as Douglas N. Daft's second in command, something M.
Douglas Ivester, Coke's outgoing chairman and chief executive,
steadfastly insisted he did not need. (Coca Cola/The New York
Times)

   (NYT26) PALO ALTO, Calif. -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- INTERNET-EQUITY --
Once thought of as outside experts who independently evaluated a
business, as an accountant or lawyer might, consultants are
becoming more like bankers whose fortunes are closely tied to their
clients. ``It is an absolutely huge change,'' says Jackson L.
Wilson, the head of Andersen Consulting's new $1 billion
venture-capital fund. (Thor Swift/The New York Times) LITE

   (NYT25) PHILADELPHIA -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- ARAMARK-BOSS --
``Today, Aramark is 93 percent owned by employees, and we've
created hundreds of millionaires,'' says Joseph Neubaueer, chief
executive of the Aramark Corp., a $7 billion managed-services
company based in Philadelphia. ``Our people sell hot dogs. They do
laundry. This is not a dot-com company. We have real earnings.''
(The New York Times)

   (NYT24) IZMIR, Turkey -- Jan. 18, 2000 --
TURKEY-CAMEL-FIGHTING-2 -- An owner stands next to his fighting
camel. As Turkey hurtles toward modernity and seeks to embrace a
European identity, camel fighting is a reminder that many Turks are
still acutely conscious of their Asian heritage. (Staton R.
Winter/The New York Times)

   (NYT23) IZMIR, Turkey -- Jan. 18, 2000 --
TURKEY-CAMEL-FIGHTING-1 -- As their respective owners and trainers
look on, two camels engage in a battle as hundreds of spectators
look on. As Turkey hurtles toward modernity and seeks to embrace a
European identity, camel fighting is a reminder that many Turks are
still acutely conscious of their Asian heritage. (Staton R.
Winter/The New York Times) LITE

   (NYT22) NEW YORK -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- YANKEES-JETER -- New York
Yankess Derek Jeter throws to first for a double play as Manny
Ramirez of the Cleveland Indians slides in vain in this July, 1999
file photo at Yankee Sadium. The Yankees are on the verge of
signing Jeter, their standout shortstop, to a seven-year
$118-million contract that would be the largest ever in
professional baseball and the second largest ever in professional
sports. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times) LITE

   (NYT21) NEW YORK -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- BATHROOM-SINKS -- From
left: A restroom basin at Thalia; the trough at the Brasserie; and
a brass sink at Metrazur. No one can accuse restaurant designers of
throwing in everything but the bathroom sink. The one detail some
diners never see has suddenly become a statement. (Elizabeth
Lippman, left; Philip Greenberg/The New York Times)

   (NYT20) NEWARK, N.J. -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- NEWARK-FIRE -- An agent
with the Bureau of Alchohol Tobacco and Firearms looks through what
is left of a candle factory a day after it was consumed in a fire,
Tuesday. Fire tore through the Mercury Candle Co. factory Monday,
sending plumes of thick smoke for miles and forcing the evacuation
of about 10 families. Firefighters continued to extinguish hotspots
Tuesday. The cause of the fire was under investigation. (Don Hogan
Charles/The New York Times)

   (NYT19) INDIANOLA, Iowa -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- GORE-CAMPAIGN --
Vice President Al Gore, running for the Democratic presidential
nomination, is joined by Andrew Cuomo, secretary of Housing and
Urban Development, during a campaign stop at Simpson College,
Tuesday. In the span of a week, Gore has made another
transformation. No longer is he attacking Bill Bradley, his leading
opponent, at every turn. And once again he's sounding very much
like the confident front-runner. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

   (NYT18) NEW YORK -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- WAITERWEAR-2 -- Waiters at
Nicole's wear black on black, left (The black pants and long-sleeve
polo shirts are conveniently for sale in the Nicole Farhi store
upstairs: $100 for the polo shirts, $170 for the pants); the gray
shirts at Quantum 56 match the restaurant's chairs. (''It's not a
monkey costume,'' says Axel Rudolph, the general manager of the
restaurant.) (Rebecca Cooney/The New York Times)

   (NYT17) NEW YORK -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- WAITERWEAR-1 -- At Isla,
blue Ultrasuede utility belts match the tiles. Setting waiters
apart isn't as easy as it once was. The old modified penguin has
been extinct at cutting-edge establishments at least since the
'60s, when waiters started wearing love beads. (Aaron Lee
Fineman/The New York Times)

   (NYT16) NEW YORK -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- TASTINGS -- For about $15
you can pick up Pikes, a riesling from Clare Valley in South
Australia which is tart and brisk with a delicious mineral tang.
Riesling is a great white grape (many say the greatest) but it has
never had the popularity of chardonnay or even sauvignon blanc in
the United States. (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times)

   (NYT15) UNDATED -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- WINETALK -- This full-bodied
Vega Sindoa merlot from Spain is about $10. Full-bodied with just
enough oak, it puts more than a few American merlots to shame.
(Tony Cenicola/The New York Times)

   (NYT14) NEW YORK -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- WINTER-STEWS -- At
Heartbeat, a vegetable stew, sprinkled with herbs and a North
African spice mixture, is served in a squash. Lately, chefs around
New York have been creating intensely flavored stews made with
vegetables only. And not just vegetarians are ordering them.
(Barbara Alper/The New York Times)

   (NYT13) NEW YORK -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- COOKING-DUCK-3 -- How to
carve a cooked duck. Step one: Holding a knife against the rib
cage, separate legs from body. Cut around the joint to cut the
thigh free. Step two: Cut away and discard any extraneous fat from
the inside of the leg and thigh, as well as any loose skin. Step 3:
Holding the knife flat against the breastbone, slice through to
separate each breast in one large piece. (Barbara Alper/The New
York Times) LITE

   (NYT12) NEW YORK -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- COOKING-DUCK-2 --
Lemon-pepper duck with glazed carrots and pilaf at Union Square
Cafe. Duck needs to be treated differently in order to get the meat
tender and moist, and the skin thin and crisp like a tuile.
(Barbara Alper/The New York Times)

   (NYT11) UNDATED -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- COOKING-DUCK-1 -- Duck
adapts to many cooking methods, including slow roasting, as shown,
pan roasting, steaming and even braising. Duck is long beyond its
days as the stuffy fare of French restaurants, and has taken on
life in all forms on restaurant menus. (Kiyoshi Togashi/The New
York Times)

   (NYT10) IOWA CITY, Iowa-- Jan. 18, 2000 -- BRADLEY-CAMPAIGN --
Bill Bradley, running for the Democratic presidential nomination,
is assisted in crossing an icy sidewalk by supporter Jim Larew on
Tuesday as Bradley arrived for a campaign appearance at West High
School. Young people can participate in Monday's precinct caucuses
as long as they'll have their 18th birthday in time for the
November election. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

   (NYT9) WASHINGTON -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- COLD-WEATHER-3 -- From
left, Michiko Nagano, Mieko Ouchi, and Kumiko Yamamoto, stand over
a steam grate to keep warm while reciting a prayer this afternoon
in the frigid winter weather. The three are visiting the United
States from Japan to do missionary work. A low pressure area
developing off the Carolinas is expected to bring snow from
Washington to New England on Thursday night, followed by brutally
cold conditions on Friday and into Saturday, said Louis Uccellini,
director of the National Centers for Environmental Prediction.
(Justin Lane/The New York Times)

   (NYT8) UNDATED -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- DUCK-CONFIT -- Ginger and
star anise, added to thyme and cloves, give an Asian twist to duck
confit. The traditional French method of simmering duck in rendered
fat tenderizes the bird, especially the legs. (Tony Cenicola/The
New York Times)

   (NYT7) TAMPA, Fla. -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- FBN-BUCS-LYNCH -- The
Tampa Bay Buccaneers' John Lynch takes a break during practice on
January 11, as team prepared for their playoff game against the
Washington Redskins this past weekend. Lynch made the key
interception in Tampa's victory on Saturday and is making a name
for himself as an NFL defensive presence. (Scott Wheeler/The
Lakeland Ledger)

   (NYT6) MERRIMACK, N.H. -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- BUSH-CAMPAIGN --
Cheerleaders at Merrimack High School listen to Gov. George Bush at
a rally in the school cafeteria on Tuesday. (Stephen Crowley/The
New York Times)

   (NYT5) WRIGHTSVILLE BEACH, N.C. -- Jan. 18, 2000 --
COLD-WEATHER-2 -- Cole Swain puts the finishing touches on his
snowman on Wrightsville Beach, Tuesday after over an inch of snow
fell across the Wilmington area. A low pressure system pushed
through the Tennessee Valley and the Mid-Atlantic states during the
day, causing snow, sleet and freezing rain to fall on eastern
Kentucky and eastern Tennessee into Virginia and the Carolinas.
(Ken Blevins/Wilmington Star-News)

   (NYT4) WRIGHTSVILLE BEACH, N.C. -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- COLD-WEATHER
-- A group of people walk on Wrightsville Beach early Tuesday after
over an inch of snow fell across the Wilmington area. A low
pressure system pushed through the Tennessee Valley and the
Mid-Atlantic states during the day, causing snow, sleet and
freezing rain to fall on eastern Kentucky and eastern Tennessee
into Virginia and the Carolinas. (Ken Blevins/Wilmington Star-News)
LITE

   (NYT3) BIG BEAR LAKE, Calif. -- Jan. 17, 2000 --
BIGBEAR-SNOWBOARDERMAN-2 -- Snowboarders get ready for a run at the
Big Bear Mountain Resort terrain park. Boarders comprise about
two-thirds of the business at Big Bear's two biggest resorts, Snow
Summit and Big Bear Mountain, which was upgraded in the off-season
to provide more thrills for snowboarders. (David Crane/Los Angeles
Daily News)

   (NYT2) BIG BEAR LAKE, Calif. -- Jan. 17, 2000 --
BIGBEAR-SNOWBOARDERMAN-1 -- Shawn Allsberry, 25, an advanced
snowboard instructor at Big Bear Mountain Resort in California's
San Bernardino Mountains, rockets off a jump in the terrain park.
The park was upgraded in the off-season to provide more thrills for
snowboarders. (David Crane/Los Angeles Daily News)

   (NYT1) JORDAN RIVER, West Bank -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- BAPTISMS --
Father Alexander, an Orthodox priest from the Ukraine, streches his
hand to help an elderly woman into the Jordan River for her baptism
on Tuesday. Dozens of Orthodox Christian pilgrims immersed
themselves in the chilly waters of the Jordan River on Tuesday.
According to Christian tradition, Jesus of Nazareth was baptised by
his cousin John in these waters. (Rina Castelnuovo/The New York
Times) LITE

   The New York Times News Service
Text:

New York Times Photo Package, moving Tuesday, 01/18/00. Photo
clients will automatically receive these photos via AP's
PhotoExpress or may download them from either the Wieck Photo
Database in Dallas at 972-392-0888 or from NYTPhotos on Newscom at
305-448-8411. Non-clients can make individual purchases by calling
(888) 603-1036 or 212-556-4204.

   (NYT1) JORDAN RIVER, West Bank -- Jan. 18, 2000 -- BAPTISMS --
Father Alexander, an Orthodox priest from the Ukraine, streches his
hand to help an elderly woman into the Jordan River for her baptism
on Tuesday. Dozens of Orthodox Christian pilgrims immersed
themselves in the chilly waters of the Jordan River on Tuesday.
According to Christian tradition, Jesus of Nazareth was baptised by
his cousin John in these waters. (Rina Castelnuovo/The New York
Times) LITE
